name: BENKO GAMBIT
uci_moves: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 c7c5 d4d5 b7b5
idea: The quintessential positional gambit! Black sacrifices a pawn (sometimes two with ...a6) to get lasting pressure on the open a and b files. This is not a gambit to mate, but to create long-term pressure. The fianchettoed Bg7 and Rooks on a8-b8 target the a2 and b2 pawns. Even in the endgame, the pressure continues! It's a gambit that White hates because it's hard to refute and boring to defend.
errors_white: Keeping the b5 pawn at all costs: this costs time and Black gets their pressure
Playing passively: White must counter-attack in the center or kingside, not defend
Neglecting development: if White plays a4, Ra3 etc. to defend, they fall behind
errors_black: Not following up on the gambit: ...Bxa6, ...d6, ...g6/...Bg7 and Rooks on a-b files quickly
Attacking too slowly: the pressure must be constant, don't let White consolidate
Forgetting the center: the d6-e6 pawns must support the queenside attack
development: The sacrifice! After cxb5 a6 bxa6, the a and b files are open
g6 then Bg7 - the Bishop targets a1 and the center on the long diagonal
Ra8 and Rb8 (or Rfb8 after castling) - pressure on a2 and b2 is the plan
Nbd7 then Nb6 - the Knight targets c4 or a4 to reinforce the pressure
Kingside castle after ...Bg7 - safe position and f8 Rook freed for b8
Qa5 or Qb6 to reinforce queenside pressure

traps.name: Full Gambit Trap
traps.desc: After 4.cxb5 a6! (second sacrifice) 5.bxa6 Bxa6 and Black has two open files for the price of two pawns. AVOID (White): Accept but counter-attack quickly in the center with e4, Nc3, Nf3.

traps.name: Diagonal Trap
traps.desc: The Ba6 targets f1, preventing natural development! If White plays e4?? the Bishop takes f1. AVOID (White): Play Nf3, e3 (not e4), then develop the Bishop to e2 or b5.

traps.name: Rook Trap
traps.desc: Typical position. Black Rooks go to a8 and b8, the Qb6 targets b2. If White is passive, the pressure becomes unbearable. AVOID (White): Play actively! e4, Re1, Bf4 and counter-attack.

variants.name: Gambit Accepted
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 c7c5 d4d5 b7b5 c4b5 a7a6 b5a6 c8a6 b1c3 d7d6 g1f3 g7g6
variants.white_plan: Counter-attack! e4 (takes space), Nd2 (protects b2), then 0-0, Re1, Bf4 and active central play.
variants.black_plan: Classical pressure. ...Bg7, ...0-0, ...Nbd7, ...Qa5 or ...Qb6, then ...Rfb8 and ...Rb8-b4 or ...Nb6-c4.

variants.name: Gambit Declined (b6)
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 c7c5 d4d5 b7b5 g1f3 g7g6 b5b6
variants.white_plan: Keeping the advanced pawn on b6 annoys Black. Develop Nc3, e4, Be2, 0-0 with space and passed pawn.
variants.black_plan: Recover the b6 pawn with ...Qxb6 or ...Bg7/...0-0/...Na6-c7xb6. The position remains imbalanced.

variants.name: Fianchetto Variation
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 c7c5 d4d5 b7b5 c4b5 a7a6 b5a6 g7g6 b1c3 c8a6 g2g3 d7d6 f1g2
variants.white_plan: Double fianchetto! The Bg2 controls the center and defends. Nf3, 0-0, Rb1, then b3 and Bb2 possible.
variants.black_plan: Both Bishops are active! ...Bg7, ...0-0, ...Nbd7-b6, ...Qa5 and the usual queenside pressure.
